children.subject:
Thank you for your response. 

How much time i should expect on EE 105 and EE 140 weekly if I take them? What is the workload of each of these two classes?

Both classes have lab component and require lab report. Roughly 10hr per week outside the class for 105. 140 has a similar workload at the beginning of the semester; however, the last month can easily go to 20hr+ per week due to the project.

140 is built completely on the knowledge from 105. You need to know everything from 105 (basic semiconductor physics and transistor models, small signal analysis, understanding of Laplace and Fourier domain, single and multi-stage transistor amplifiers) to do well in 140. Of course, professors of 140 will give a quick review of 105 for the first 2 weeks; nevertheless, you are expected to spend extra time in 140 if you have less solid background. 
I know people who skipped 105, but they typically didn’t plan on doing analog IC design. If that’s the case, you can probably self study 105 material by watching webcasts from previous semester. 
Just as a reference, suppose you ask me to rate the difficulty of some EE classes out of 10, I will give 2 to EE16A&B, 3 to EE120, 4 to EE105, 7 to EE140, and 8 to EECS151+lab.

history.content:
It's always great to hear people getting excited about analog circuit design!  I will give my perspective from the 140 class taught by Pister, though the comments likely apply to Mueller's class as well. I have taken 105 and 140, and have TA'd both classes as well, and I will try to give both the student's and TA's perspectives combined.

Things to note: 

1.  As anon below mentioned, 140 is a continuation of 105.  That being said, the first midterm is typically a brush-up of 105.  This is the part that you will have to spend time on to catch up, and then you will be good to go.  The knowledge required here:

    -> Small signal analysis of single and multiple stage designs.  Pister spends a decent chunk of time in this part in 140, which should help.  Note that this should be done by inspection, not nodal analysis.

    -> Frequency response of circuits & the miller effect by inspection using open-circuit time constant approximations.  this is assumed knowledge in 140 and not covered.  Therefore, one should go over this thoroughly; I'd recommend using Ali Niknejad's lectures from previous semesters for instance here.

    ->  Basics of differential pairs.  While this is after the 1st midterm in pister's 140, it's still good to have an idea of what happens.  

    -> Gain-Bandwidth product of feedback in amplifiers (voltage feedback).  There's a lot online on this, and it's pretty straightforward.

2.  Analog design relies heavily on intuition, therefore practice is key-> practice enough (or for better time efficiency, make use of office hours) so that problems can be solved by inspection or described in words; nodal analysis is only used when all else fails!  

3.  Be aware that 16a/b do not give any hint whatsoever (like absolutely nothing) as to what analog design is about, so recognize that taking this path is a bit of a gamble.  

4.  For the comments below, Laplace/fourier analysis is not expected, since it's not done in 105 (you should take 120 before you graduate, regardless of what you chose to do in EE), while device physics is briefly mentioned in 140, it's usually just for 1 homework and can be self-taught (I recommend chenming Hu's free 130 textbook), or better yet take 130. Do not take 105 solely for device physics, it does a rushed job of it, and 130 starts from the beginning anyways.  Ultimately in circuit design, we abstract out the physics anyways (though interviewers do like asking device physics questions).

If you do decide to jump ahead and take 140, I would not take 105; it will just burden you unbearably in terms of work, 140 is not bad until the project (for pister, muller's project is comparatively easy), but 105 is a lot of work.  Also the timelines don't match, since the beginning of 140 is the last 1/3 of 105.  Taking 105 only and not 140 will not give enough knowledge to get a job/be useful in the field.

So in summary, you will have to work very hard in the beginning or over summer to catch up, but it is doable (and I'm always in favor of doing things like this, don't be afraid to drop if need be).  The hardest part will be gaining the intuition, since such things come from experience/teaching.  But the good part is by the end of 140, if you understand the material well it is indeed possible to get an analog design job (though companies would prefer some experience for what they consider 'masters-level' work, so intern or do research as well)!

Cheers and good luck!

Hi, 

I want to take EE140 but I do not have any space to take both EE 140 and EE 105.

Is that ok for me to self teach myself 105 materials before taking EE 140?

What should I know from 105 to take 140?

Thanks
history.subject: Take EE 140 without EE105
